Create love plots showing balancing statistics

Source: R/make_love_plot.R
make_love_plot.Rd

Create love plots showing balancing statistics

Usage

make_love_plot(
  balance_stats,
  exposure,
  exposure_time_pt,
  exposure_type,
  k = 0,
  form_name,
  data_type,
  balance_thresh,
  weights_method,
  imp_conf,
  save.out = FALSE,
  home_dir = NULL,
  folder = NULL,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

balance_stats

data frame of balance statistics

exposure

name of exposure variable

exposure_time_pt

exposure time point integer

exposure_type

character indicating binary or continuous exposure type

k

imputation number

form_name

formula name

data_type

single or imputed data type

balance_thresh

one or two numbers between 0 and 1 indicating a single balancing threshold or thresholds for more and less important confounders, respectively

weights_method

method character string of WeightItMSM() balancing method abbreviation

imp_conf

list of variable names reflecting important confounders

save.out

TRUE or FALSE indicator to save output and intermediary output locally

home_dir

path to home directory (required if save.out = TRUE)

folder

folder path for saving

verbose

(optional) TRUE or FALSE indicator for user output (default is TRUE)

Value

none

Examples

f <- createFormulas(exposure = "A",
                    exposure_time_pts = c(1, 2, 3),
                    outcome = "D.3",
                    tv_confounders = c("A.1", "A.2", "A.3", "B.1", "B.2", "B.3"),
                    ti_confounders = "C",
                    type = "full",
                    save.out = FALSE)
#> USER ALERT: Please manually inspect the full balancing formula below:
#> The full formula for A - D.3 at A time point 1 is: 
#> A.1 ~ C
#> <environment: 0x555b196c1478>
#> 
#> USER ALERT: Please manually inspect the full balancing formula below:
#> The full formula for A - D.3 at A time point 2 is: 
#> A.2 ~ A.1 + B.1 + C
#> <environment: 0x555b196c1478>
#> 
#> USER ALERT: Please manually inspect the full balancing formula below:
#> The full formula for A - D.3 at A time point 3 is: 
#> A.3 ~ A.1 + A.2 + B.1 + B.2 + C
#> <environment: 0x555b196c1478>
#> 

test <- data.frame(ID = 1:50,
                   A.1 = rnorm(n = 50),
                   A.2 = rnorm(n = 50),
                   A.3 = rnorm(n = 50),
                   B.1 = rnorm(n = 50),
                   B.2 = rnorm(n = 50),
                   B.3 = rnorm(n = 50),
                   C = rnorm(n = 50),
                   D.3 = rnorm(n = 50))
test[, c("A.1", "A.2", "A.3")] <- lapply(test[, c("A.1", "A.2", "A.3")], as.numeric)

w <- createWeights(data = test,
                   exposure = "A",
                   outcome = "D.3",
                   formulas = f,
                   save.out = FALSE)
#> For the cbps weighting method, the median weight value is 0.97 (SD = 0.53; range = 0.34-3). 
#> 


b <- assessBalance(data = test,
                   exposure = "A",
                   exposure_time_pts = c(1, 2, 3),
                   outcome = "D.3",
                   type = "weighted",
                   weights = w,
                   formulas = f,
                   save.out = FALSE)
#> USER ALERT: The following statistics display covariate imbalance at each exposure time point following IPTW weighting, using full formulas.
#> 



#> As shown below, 2 out of 9 (22%) covariates across time points, corresponding to 2 out of 3 domains, remain imbalanced with a remaining median absolute value correlation/std mean difference of 0.14 (range= -0.15-0.13):
#> 
#> Table: Imbalanced covariates using cbps and full formulas
#> 
#> | exp_time| balanced_n| imbalanced_n|  n|
#> |--------:|----------:|------------:|--:|
#> |        1|          1|            0|  1|
#> |        2|          2|            1|  3|
#> |        3|          4|            1|  5|
#> 
#> 
#> USER ALERT: For exposure A using the full formulas and cbps :
#> The median absolute value relation between exposure and confounder is 0.03 (range = -0.15 -0.13). 
#> As shown below, the following 2 covariates across time points out of 9 total (22.22%) spanning 2 domains out of 3 (66.67%) are imbalanced with a remaining median absolute value correlation/std mean difference in relation to A of 0.14 (range=-0.15-0.13) :
#> 
#> 
#> Table: Imbalanced Covariates
#> 
#> |   |exposure | exp_time| covar_time|covariate |    avg_bal| bal_thresh| balanced|
#> |:--|:--------|--------:|----------:|:---------|----------:|----------:|--------:|
#> |3  |A        |        2|          1|B.1       | -0.1497486|        0.1|        0|
#> |6  |A        |        3|          2|A.2       |  0.1309331|        0.1|        0|
#> 

make_love_plot(balance_stats = b,
               exposure = "A",
               exposure_time_pt = 1,
               exposure_type = "continuous",
               form_name = "form_name",
               data_type = "single",
               balance_thresh = 0.1,
               imp_conf = NULL,
               weights_method = w[[1]]$method,
               save.out = FALSE,
               folder = "prebalance/")


make_love_plot(balance_stats = b,
               exposure = "A",
               exposure_time_pt = 2,
               exposure_type = "continuous",
               form_name = "form_name",
               data_type = "single",
               balance_thresh = c(0.05, 0.1),
               imp_conf = "A.2",
               weights_method = w[[1]]$method,
               save.out = FALSE,
               folder = "weighted/")
